rally go by the name of Henry—I have not taken any other name—I am a Roman Catholic—I go by the name of Henry—(looking at a letter)—this is not my writing—I solemnly swear it is not—(the witness was here directed to write his name, also the words, "My dear wife")—I persist in swearing that letter is not my writing—I believe you will find one letter among those inclosed ones which she sent to me, in which I say I treated her with contempt—this is it—that is my writing.
COURT. Q. Did you ever live with the prisoner? A. Never—I merely
spoke to her occasionally, nothing further—the is a loose character, and I have had connexion with her, as well at other men have.
GEORGE CASELEY . I saw the prosecutor on Whit-Monday—he was not married that day to anybody at Paddington church.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you related to the prosecutor? A. No—I have known him about three months—I was helping him all that day—I have no sister—I am not in any way connected with the family.

Prosecutor. My name is Patrick Henry—I am called Patrick Henry, since the day I was at the office—I went by that name, because they said it was necessary—before that I used generally to be called Henry—I was confirmed in 1827—before that I was called Patrick only, and after that I was generally called Henry—my mother used always to call me Patrick Henry—I generally call myself Patrick Henry, but before I went to the Police-office, Henry, generally—my mother always called me Patrick Henry after my confirmation—I was confirmed by the name of Henry only—I did not give up the name of Patrick—the bishop called me Henry, by my desire.

JURY. Q. At the time of your marriage what name did you sign? A. I was married to my first wife—she is now dead—I signed Henry, not Patrick—I was married by banns, and called Henry—I never had any other wife—when the gentleman spoke, I thought he might allude to this party, whom I know nothing about—she has no claim to meat all—on any solemn occasion, such as being sworn, I call myself Patrick Henry—(the signature to the certificate found on the prisoner was Patrick Henry Smith.)
NOT GUILTY .

2154.
BRIDGET SMITH was again indicted
for feloniously attempt
ing to administer to
Catherine Smith a large quantity of oxalic acid, with intent to murder her.

THOMAS HYETT . On Friday, the 26th of Sept., I saw the prisoner in Church-street, Cornwall-road—she gave me a brown paper parcel, and told me to take it to No. 3, Pier's Cooperage, to tell Mrs. Smith to get tea ready, and she would come—I took the parcel, and delivered it to Mrs. Smith—I am sure the prisoner is the person.

CATHERINE SMITH . On Friday, the 26th of Sept., I received a parcel from Hyett—it contained lump and moist sugar, and a little tea in another paper—I took it and showed it afterwards to my son, and to Mrs. Pem
berton—I gave it to my son in the same state as Hyett had given it to me.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANB. Q. Did you expect that evening, after what Hyett told you, that some woman would come and drink tea with you? A. No—he told me a woman was coming to drink tea, but he did not mention her—I expected a woman to come to tea, from what he said, but not the prisoner—I could not expect anybody to come till I heard what the boy said—he said a woman was coming to tea, and to have the kettle boiling.
COURT. Q. When he said that, did you think anybody would come? A. No—I said to myself, "I don't know who sent it;" nor did I expect the tea from anybody.
ELIZABETH PEMBERTON . On the 26th of Sept., I went to Mrs. Smith's—she gave her son a parcel in my presence—I saw him take it to Mr. Handley's in the state it was in.

HENRY SMITH . On the 26th of Sept., I went to my mother's house—I live there—she showed me a paper parcel, containing lump and moist sugar, and tea in a separate paper—I took it with Mrs. Pemberton to Mr. Handley, in the same state as my mother delivered it to me.

JURY. Q. How came you to take it to Mr. Handley? A. In conse
quence of tricks I have heard the prisoner used to make I looked at the sugar, and saw there was a difference in it—the tricks were against me.

JAMES HANDLEY . I received the parcel from Smith—the larger por
tion of it was moist sugar—there was oxalic acid in it, I am positive from what I observed, from the taste, the appearance, and its effervescing—it had no smell—it is very difficult to say how much there was, without the whole was analysed—I should say there was an ounce, or two—a less quantity than that would kill a person—it depends on the peculiar con
stitution of the person—I believe as little as two drachms has been known to kill—that is a quarter of an ounce.

SARAH WIGGINS . I have heard the prisoner say, after mentioning to me, that she would poison the man if she could, that she would poison the wretch of an old woman if she could, for it was through her ill treat
ment that she was ill treated in the way she was—this was about six weeks ago.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you ever said this to anybody before? A. I mentioned it to Mr. Smith—I was examined before the Magistrate—I did not say anything about the mother then.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Whom did you mention it to? A. To Mr. Smith, and Mrs. Smith heard me.
MARY MCNALLY . I heard the prisoner say she would poison Smith if she could—I understood that to mean my brother.

JAMES HANDLEY
re-examined. I do not profess to analyse—I sent the parcel to Mr. Simpson by Smith, who brought it back to me four or five days afterwards, saying the gentleman declined analysing it, as he could not pay him for it.

HENRY SMITH
re-examined. I took the stuff from Mr. Handley to Mr. Simpson, and brought it from him to the police-station the same day—I did not leave it with Mr. Simpson at all—I gave him a portion of it to test—I brought the rest away at the same time, and took it to the police-station—it never passed from my sight—I never received a present of that kind, or anything from the prisoner.

THOMAS HICKMAN (policeman). I had this from Smith—I took it to the station, and left it there in custody of the inspector, who locked it up—he is not here—it is usual to keep all property there—it was in the place where property is usually kept—I took it from there afterwards to the police-court—there is a little room at the station for the express purpose—I did not see it put in there, but left in the charge-room—I did not see it taken from there—I received it from the inspector to take to the office—he received it from me, and gave it me back—after the prisoner was re
manded I took it back to the station-house, and lost sight of it in the same way—I received it again to take at the second examination—I then took it back to the station the third time, and brought it from there to take before the Grand Jury—I then took it back to the station, and brought it here myself—I had left it in charge of the inspector in the charge-room—we are bound to take everything to the inspector—and when we want them we apply to him, and he gives them to us.
Prisoner. I have witnesses; he told a gentleman if he could not make away with me, he would either hang or transport me.

HENRY SMITH
cross-examined by MR. CARTEEN. I know Anthony Cunningham very well—I have heard my mother say he is a relation of mine, but I do not know it—he was at my sister's the day the prisoner was there—I never said I would make away with her—I never said to him that I would make away with her if it was not for the laws of my country—I swear that, nor anything to that effect, nor that if I did not make away with her I would transport her—I never uttered such words—I never said I would endeavour to transport her—I swear that—I have certainly said I would endeavour to get rid of her by legal means, by the law of my country, by applying to a Magistrate—I have applied to a Magistrate to know whether I am justified in bringing her before him for saying she was married to me—I do not know that I have used those words to Cunning
ham—I have said it to my mother and other persons who have spoken to me about the concern—I have even said it to the witnesses who have been examined, that I would get rid of her by legal means, so far as the law would allow—I never said I would transport her.

ANTHONY CUNNINGHAM . I know the prosecutor, but I never had any Conversation with him—he told me he would wear the feet to the knees and the fingers to the elbows, or else send her out of the country—that was about last July—I did not hear him say he would transport her—he said he would make away with her, if it was not for the laws of the country—and another thing, he told me he gave charge of her to Sergeant Bennett, letter D 18, and said he knew her, between five and six years ago, to be in the family way, and that stie put the child in a basket and put it in the workhouse, but it was found to be a falsehood, and the prisoner was discharged—Sergeant Bennett made inquiry, and it was no such thing.

MR. PRENDBROAST. Q. I believe you threatened to knock Smith's brains out, did you not? A. Not a bit—he came in to me one Sunday night rather in liquor, and wanted to search my place—I said, "If you have any authority you may, but not without," for the prisoner was not in my place—there was no policeman with him—I said, "If a policeman comes up, my place is open for any one to search," but the prisoner was not in my place at the time—I am a married man and a grandfather—I know nothing at all about the woman, no further than seeing her in the apparel of a woman, as for any carnal knowledge of her, I had none—she never lodged at my house—he wanted to make out she was in my place, whereas she was not, and I ordered him out—he insisted on searching my place, and I told him he should not—no officer came.

JOHN THOMAS . I work at plastering. I live at No. 15, Camden-place, Kensington—the prisoner is my mother—one Monday morning (I do not know the date) the prosecutor came with me from my mother a house across the fields—he said, "John, would you like me to get married to your mother?"—I did not make him any answer, for I never liked him—he then said he was going to get married to my mother on the same morn
ing—I went with him across the fields into the main road, and he then parted from me—I remember on a Friday, about five weeks back, going with my mother to High-street office to take out a warrant—I was in her company that day from about one o'clock till half-past five o'clock—I was
out of her company a few minutes at High-street office—I did not leave her there—we went on to Kingsgate-street, and I came back with her from Kingsgate-street.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did your mother take out any summons that day? A. She did not tell me—she went to Kingsgate-street and took a summons out, but she went to High-street for a warrant—she did not tell me whether she got one or not—she told me she had been talking to Mr. Whip, but she did not tell me any more—I was with her—I did not hear her ask the Magistrate for any warrant.

Q. You have been giving evidence here in marriage cases before, have you not? A. Yes—I do not know which was the last time—it was a charge of bigamy—I was a witness, and gave evidence of a marriage of my mother to a man on the Easter Monday in 1844, I think—the man set up a story that he was not the man, but that my mother had married some
body else in his name, but she was married to him, for I saw her—I was present at the church—there was another witness, a woman—I have known my mother married once, and I believe she was married the second time—I have heard of a man named Sheehan, but I do not know him—I cannot say whether I have seen him or not—I do not recollect ever seeing him—no man of that name ever lived along with my mother—she was married to M'Cann on Easter Monday, 1844—I believe she married again after that.

THOS. HYETT
re-examined. I did not know Mr. or Mrs. Smith before—when the prisoner gave me the parcel she said, "Take that to Mrs. Smith," telling me she lived at No. 3, Pier's Cooperage—I knew Pier's Cooperage, and No. 3—I am not able to read the numbers—I found out No. 3 by asking a little girl down there if she knew a person named Smith at No. 3—I asked the neighbours, and they told me, and I went to the third house down—the policeman came to take me to the police-office.

THOS. HICKMAN
re-examined. I found out Hyett through the prose
cutor—I went with him to the boy's house.

HENRY SMITH
re-examined. I inquired of the neighbours if they knew the little boy that had brought the parcel, and it happened that some of the children in the Cooperage knew him, and by that means took me to his place.

THOS. HYETT
re-examined. A little girl in the Cooperage, named Logan, knew where I lived—I did not ask her where Mrs. Smith lived—I went to the third house down and asked, and it was not there—they said it was at the other third door—I went to the other third door, and that was Mrs. Smith's.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2155.
JOHN SNAZELL was indicted
for a rape.
NOT GUILTY .

2156.
RICHARD HODNOTT and
SOLOMON LYONS were indict
ed for
feloniously assaulting
William Dolby, on the 14th of Oct., putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 watch, value 4l.; 1 handkerchief, 2s. 6d.; and 2 breast-pins and chain, 7s. 6d., his goods; and immediately before, at the time of, and after the said robbery, beating, striking, and using other personal violence to him, and that Hodnott had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM DOLBY . I was a City police-constable, and lived at the police-tation, Great Tower-street; I live there now. On the night of the 14th of Oct. I was at the Surrey theatre, and left about a quarter after twelve—Esworthy was with me—we left the theatre together, and went to a cigar shop two or three doors from the theatre—we afterwards went into the Bridge-house public-house in our way home, between the theatre and the Queen's bench prison—I went to the bar and saw both the prisoners in front of the bar, not standing together at first—there might be nearly twenty persons in the house altogether—there were two or three women, and the rest men—I afterwards observed the prisoners standing together—the first thing that occurred to me was, I was struck a severe blow on the left cheek by the prisoner Lyons—I had not spoken to either of them—I turned my head round to my left, where Lyons was, and said, "What is that for?"—I thought something might have occurred, and that it was an accidental blow—Esworthy tried to come to my assistance, but was prevented by Hodnott, who struck him a blow which knocked him back towards the corner—I did not see other persons prevent him—I then received another blow from Lyons, which knocked off my hat, and from that a silk hand
kerchief vanished—I was then struck another blow on the breast, and knocked on one side near the tap of the bar—Lyons then turned round, and, with his left hand, snatched my stock and pin—I had a watch in my left pocket, with a silver guard round my neck—I lost that, but do not know who took it—it went at the first blow I was struck—Lyons turned to the left, and escaped by the side door—I followed him as quick at I could out at the side door; but before I could get quite to the door, it was closed against me for about a minute—I got out, saw a constable outside, and gave him information—I saw Lyons running when I got out at the door, but lost sight of him—he was apprehended about twenty minutes or half an hour after—I have not seen my watch or handkerchief since—I have seen my stock and a portion of the pin in the hands of the constable—it was a union pin—the chain is gone from it, except three or four links—I have no doubt whatever of the prisoners being the men.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL ANT INE. Q. When did you retire from the police? A. Yesterday morning my time expired—I resigned, having sent in a month's notice—I was not in my uniform on this night—I had a night's leave to go out—the public-house was in my way home—I had never been into it before—I went in quite by accident—I think Esworthy had been in the house before, but he did not know it at the time—it was the first house that was open—we were smoking when we went in—I spoke to one of the women—I did not put my arm round her waist, nor touch her, that I know of; if I did, it was with my arm as she stepped up between me and my friend—she spoke to my friend first, and to me afterwards—she asked him to treat her—he refused—she then asked me, and I refused—I mentioned that at the Police-court—the land-lord had served me with a pint of half-and-half—I drank out of it, and set it down to Esworthy-before he drank, she asked him again to treat her—and he said, "If you like you can drink out of that"—she put it to her lips, but whether she drank any I do not know
this was before I received the blow
I was on one side of her and Esworthy on the other—it took a very short time—I might be there five minutes or more before any blow was struck—I did not speak to any other woman—I think there

were two or three in the room—Hodnott did not come up to me—he said nothing to me—I cannot say that he came up while I was talking to the woman—I will swear he did not speak to me—he was close to me—he said nothing to the woman that I know of—the landlord was there—he served me—I was not turned out of the house, nor was Esworthy, to my knowledge—I was not there when he left.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. I suppose there was some noise? A. Not much—there was talking—I was talking to my friend while the woman stood between us—I said nothing else to her—she stepped up between us as soon as we went to the bar—there was no disturbance in the room, only what took place between the prisoners and me—the door was shut against me after Lyons got out, by parties connected with him, I have no doubt—there was a short struggle to get out at the door, but no particular violence—the bar is in an oval direction—I do not know who snatched my watch—it was taken at the time I received the first blow on my cheek—I did not turn round to strike again, but to ask what it was for—I also received a slight cut on my left hand, which appeared to be from a sharp instrument—the chain which fastened the pin was a thin gold chain—the two ends of my stock came out, and the chain was broken.

MR. PARRY. Q. I suppose there was a black satin front to the stock? A. Yes, that was torn off—I did not receive the least assistance from the landlord, or anybody in the house—I was prevented from leaving the house by other parties besides the prisoners—my watch was in my left waistcoat-pocket—I had on the coat I have now—it was not buttoned—the chain was visible.

ROBERT ESWORTHY . I am a clerk, at present out of a situation; I lodge at No. 68, Lower Thames-street. I have known Dolby three years—I was in his company on the evening of the 14th of Oct. at the Surrey theatre—we left at about a quarter past twelve o'clock—we went into a cigar shop, and afterwards into the Bridge-house public-house, Borough-road, in our way home—there were fifteen or twenty persons standing at the bar—a girl spoke to us—I did not treat her—she drank out of the half-and-half which we had—while standing at the bar, Hodnott and one who is not in custody came up to me, and asked if I knew a young man named George, who, the person not in custody told me, was in the detec
tive force, and he went on telling me he would give any money to find him—I asked him what his other name was—he said Townsend, and I told him I did not know the name (he said he himself belonged to the detec
tive force, and was under the Forresters, and said he was stationed round the Bank) I then heard Dolby say, "What is that for?" and I saw him and Lyons scuffling together—as I was going to Dolby's assistance I received a severe blow from Hodnott, and fell down—on getting up Hodnott knocked me down again—I got up, and saw Lyons rush out of the house, and Dolby after him—there was one man at the door, who prevented Dolby going out—others surrounded and struck me—I got up, and put my hands up to my eyes to save them from being blackened, but I had a black eye the next morning—after receiving several severe blows for five or six minutes, I managed to get out of the house, and on going up the street I saw Dolby and the policeman talking together—I afterwards saw Lyons in custody (about one o'clock, or ten minutes after)—Hodnott remained behind—I saw him taken about one o'clock the same morning—I afterwards saw Dolby's pin, without the chain, found on the
floor in front of the bar—neither the landlord, nor anybody, rendered me any assistance.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You went in with cigars in your mouths, did you not? A. Yes—there were three or four women inside—one woman was standing in front of us—we did not touch her at all—she asked me to treat her—I said, "No"—then she asked Dolby, and he said, "Here is some half-and-half, if you like to drink out of it"—I lost nothing—I had no watch, chain, or purse—I had a few shillings in my pocket—I was not turned out of the place.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. When you turned round how were Lyons and Dolby? A. Scuffling together, with their hands on each other—that lasted till Lyons rushed out—I saw nothing till I heard Dolby say "What is that for?"
MR. PARRY. Q. Were any other persons smoking besides you? A. Hodnott was smoking a pipe—I did not observe any more smoking.

JOHN WISE (police-constable M 84.) In consequence of information, I apprehended Hodnott, about half-past twelve o'clock, on the morning of. the 15th, in James-street, Union-street, Borough-road, in the street—Dolby had him on the ground when I came up—I told him he must come with me for the assault and robbery—he said, "Very well, I will go with you, John"—I know the Bridge-house perfectly well—it is generally open till two or three o'clock in the morning—it is a general practice for persons to be smoking there.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. That observation applies to every house, does it not? A. Yes.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. You found the stock and pin? A. The front of the stock was found by the landlord, who is here—I did not see him pick it up—I saw him stoop in front of the bar—that was within a quarter of an hour after I had apprehended Hodnott, about one or half-past.
MR. PARRY. Q. Were Dolby and Hodnott struggling? A. Not at the time—Esworthy was there, and two or three other persons—there was a female there—I know her—she is connected with Hodnott.

COURT. Q. Did either party call you? A. Esworthy called me—Dolby and Esworthy were together at first, going in pursuit of Lyons—Hodnott passed us, and Dolby said he thought he was one of the party—Hodnott was drunk.

FREDERICK LITCHFIELD (police-constable M 50.) Between twelve and one o'clock in the morning of the 15th of Oct. I saw Dolby and Esworthy—in consequence of information they gave me, I apprehended Lyons in King-street, Union-street, Borough-road, about a quarter before one o'clock—Dolby and Esworthy were not present—I told him I wanted him for the job at the Bridge-house—he said, "What is that?"—I said, "Assault and robbery"—he said he knew nothing about it; he had just been to take brandy-faced Poll home, as she was drunk.
THOMAS REDFORD (policeman.) I produce a certificate of Hodnott's former conviction—(read)—I was present at the trial, and am certain he is the man.

HODNOTT—
GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Transported for Twenty Years.

LYONS—
GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

2157.
MARY MORRIS was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
William Charles Richard Limposs, on the 25th of Sept., putting him in fear, and stealing from his person, and against his will, 2 half-crowns, 3 shillings, and 1 sixpence, his monies.

WILLIAM CHARLES RICHARD LIMPOSS . I am a tide-waiter in the Cus
toms, and live in Adam-street, Rotherhithe. On Thursday, the 24th of Sept., a few minutes past eleven o'clock at night, I was at the door of No. 62, King-street, Borough, in the act of ringing my daughter's bell, when the prisoner came up to me, caught me by the coat, and gave me a violent push, in consequence of which I fell—I had 8s. 6d. in my pocket—there were two new half-crowns, three shillings, and one sixpence—she put her hand into my pocket—she ran away—as soon as I recovered I fol
lowed her—she was never out of my sight—the policeman stopped her about three or four doors from my daughter's—I missed the two half-crowns and the three shillings and sixpence from my pocket—I told the policeman to hold her, for she had robbed me—I am positive my money had been safe in my pocket about four or five minutes before—I saw some half-crowns before Mr. Traill next day—I could not swear to them.

MARY ANN RANDALL . I am a searcher of females at the station in Black man-street, Borough. I had to search the prisoner in the cell one night last month—I do not remember what night it was—I think it was the 5th of Sept.—I think it was in the early part of the month—she took something from her bosom—I asked what it was—she said, "It is the money you are looking for,"(giving me two half-crowns,)" put it into your pocket, and say nothing about it, and I will never tell"—she repeated that several times, and said she was quite sure, if I told of it, it would transport her—I produce the money.

Prisoner. I solemnly swear I never said such a thing; I said it was what the gentleman gave me, and it was a hard thing to be locked up for nothing; she knows it is false, neither did she mention it to the inspector, or say a word of what she states now till she went before the Magistrate in the morning; the gentleman gave me the money, and he wanted it back again, after he had taken indecent liberties with me; I was with him from eleven o'clock; I met him against St. Thomas's-street, as the clock facing the hospital was striking eleven.
W. C. R. LIMPOSS re-examined. I did not give her the money—I took no indecent liberty with her, nor even spoke to her—she came upon me at an unguarded moment.

JOHN SIMS (policeman.) I was on duty at the time the prisoner was searched—it was on the night of the 25th of Sept.—I saw the prosecutor in High-street, Borough—he was alone—I saw him turn down King-street—no one was with him then—the prisoner, in company with another fe
male, was following close behind him—she left the other female, crossed over to the side he was walking on, and went up King-street—I saw the prosecutor standing at the door, as though waiting to be admitted—I did not see him ring the bell, I was not near enough—I saw the prisoner walk up close behind him—I saw him fall, and saw her in a stooping position over him—I was about 100 yards off—I saw her leave the prosecutor—he got up and called, "Stop her, she has robbed me"—I stopped her, took her to the station, and she was searched that night—the prosecutor went with me to the station—he said, in the prisoner's presence, that she had robbed him of two half-crowns—she said he was mistaken, it must be another person! she came up the other way—this was before she was searched,
when she was first accused—on the way to the station the prosecutor said they were two new half-crowns—the money found on her corresponded with his description.

Prisoner's Defence. When he came to take me we were both on the ground; the gentleman had me by the throat—he accused me of robbing him of 5s.; I said, "No, it is false;" the policeman asked what I had in my hand; I said that was nothing to him, what I had I should give up to his betters; I am quite innocent; the prosecutor told me to follow him; I asked him to treat me to something to drink; he said he could not, for he was too near his home, and did not wish to be seen.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2158.
SARAH HUGHES was indicted
for the wilful murder of a certain female child.
(From the evidence of the medical witness, it appeared that the death might have been caused in the effort of self-delivery.)
NOT GUILTY .

2159.
ANN SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Oct, 1 shawl, value 12s., the goods of
John Cope Folkard.

JAMES GEORGE POOLE . I am shopman to Mr. John Cope Folkard, a pawnbroker, in the London-road. On Friday evening, the 24th of Oct., about five o'clock, I was taking in the goods from the door—I saw the prisoner pulling different things about, and asking the prices—I went into the shop with some of the goods I was moving, and when I returned to the door a gown was partly pulled down—I told the prisoner to go on, as she did not want to buy anything—she went outside, and I saw her pull down a shawl, put it under her arm, and go away—I followed, and took the shawl from under her arm—this now produced is it—it is Mr. Folkard's property.
Prisoner. I was very much in liquor at the time, and did not remember the shawl till I was at the station. Witness. I do not think the was; she pretended to be so.
JOHN PAYNE (policeman.) I took her into custody—she did not appear intoxicated.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Two Months.

2160.
JANET STEWART was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of June, 1 pepper-eastor, value 1s.; 1 salt-cellar, 1s.; 1 printed book, 1s.; and 1 knife, 1s.; the goods of
Robert Cole, her master.

ROBERT COLE . I am a pawnbroker, and live in East-street, Walworth; the prisoner was in my service, and left on the 19th of June. On the 20th of Oct. Eleanor Stewart came and told me something, which caused me to go to No. 2, Union-row—I there-found a book, pepper-castor, salt-cellar, and" knife of mine—they were given up to me by Eleanor Stewart—I then went with Baker to No. 8, Union-row, found the prisoner, and gave her into custody—these are the articles—they were safe in my house while the prisoner was with me.
ELEANOR STEWART . I am the prisoner's sister, and live at No. 2, Union-row. About four months ago I went to see my sister, while she was

living with Mr. Cole—she did not give me anything then—when she left her place I asked her for a few halfpence, as I was very badly off, and she gave me these things—she was living at home then, at No. 8, Union-row—it is about four months ago—I took them away—these are the same things—I delivered them to Mr. Cole—she asked me if my father had ever read this book—I said I did not know—she said, "Well, give it to him and let him read it"—that was after she had left Mr. Cole.

JAMES BAKER (policeman.) I took the prisoner and told her the charge—she said it was all spite—next day, when locked up at the station I heard her say that she did give her sister the pepper-castor—she made a statement before the Magistrate, which was taken down—this is Mr. Henry's handwriting—(read)—"The prisoner says,—I lent the book to my father to read; my sister took it to him, and I intended her to bring it back, but I never could get it back, my father thinking it was my own; the other things I gave Eleanor to buy bread for herself and father, as she said they were in want of it."

Prisoner Defence. My sister came to me at Mr. Cole's one morning before Mr. Cole was up, and asked for some money, and something else to make away with; I said I had nothing; she went to the cupboard and saw this pepper-box and salt-cellar, and asked me for them; she laid them on the table; I said she might take them if she thought proper; she pledged them for 9d., and made away with the money; four months afterwards she owed me a little spite, and she took them out of pledge, and took them to Mr. Cole.

ELEANOR STEWART
re-examined. She gave them to me at home, at her mother's house—I will not be sure whether she had left her place or not.
MR. COLS re-examined. The witness in her former examination stated that she did come to my house, and took them from there.

ELEANOR STEWART
re-examined. I signed this examination, but they had a solicitor, and he stupified me so that I did not know what I was saying—(The witness's deposition being read, stated,—"About four months ago I went to see my sister, the prisoner, when she was living with Mr. Cole, and she gave me a knife, pepper-castor, and salt-cellar, which I carried away.")
NOT GUILTY .

2161.
THOMAS HYNES was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining a pair of slippers, by false pretences, to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

2162.
JAMES WHITEMAN was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining 5 dozen wheelbarrows, from
Samuel Mills, by false pretences: also on two other charges for obtaining goods from
John Bennet and
Thomas Gurney, by false pretences, to all which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

2163.
MATTHEW HENRY CHILLINGWORTH
was in
dicted for embezzlement.

JOHN HAY . I am the keeper of the Surrey Asylum. I was in
debted

to Mr. Bennett 5l. 7s.—I sent my man with a check of 11l. 5s. to pay that—this is the check—my man came back—I received 5l. 18s. in change—that was the amount I ought to have received if the amount I owed to Mr. Bennet had been paid, with the exception of 2 1/2d., which they generally throw off—I have no recollection when I sent the check—it is dated on the 1st of Aug., and I had had it by me some two or three days before I sent it—one Sunday morning, a week or two afterwards, the prisoner came with Harris, who makes out Mr. Bennett's bills—Harris said in the prisoner's presence that there was something wrong about a sovereign that was paid short—he asked me what I had paid—I told him I had given Sharpe, my man, a check for 11l. 5s., and when be came back he brought me 5l. 18s., and the bill receipted—this is the bill.

JOHN SHARPE . I am servant to Mr. Hay—on the 4th of Aug. he sent me with a check—I do not know whether this is the check—it was wrapped in a bit of paper—what Mr. Hay gave me I took to Mr. Bennett's—I gave the check to the prisoner—I did not tell him anything—he got change and gave me the change and this bill—I took it back to my master—there were five sovereigns, and some silver—I did not count the silver.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you any conversation with the prisoner about the amount? A. No, I merely gave him the check in a piece of paper—I counted the sovereigns I received back, but not the silver—I just took what he gave me—I was in Mr. Bennett's shop when I gave the prisoner the check—there were one or two people in the shop—I do not know where he got change for the check—he went out to get it, and came the way of the London-road.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Whatever money the prisoner gave you, you car
ried to your master? A. Yes—I carried it all the way in my hand.

DEBORAH BENNETT . I am the wife of Solomon Bennett—I recollect, on the 4th of Aug., the prisoner gave me 4l. 7s., and said Mr. Hay bad paid his bill—it might have been about eleven or twelve o'clock in the day—the prisoner then went to the book, and I saw him writedown 4l. 7s.—this is the book, and this is his handwriting, "Hay paid bill, 4l. 7s."

Cross-examined. Q. In whose handwriting is this bill and receipt? A. The items I cannot say—my husband makes out the bills sometimes, and sometimes Harris does—I think this is my husband's writing—my sight is very bad—Mr. Hay owed 5l. 7s., and the prisoner gave me 4l. 7s.—I did not know the amount Mr. Hay owed—I am not always in the shop—I know the prisoner brought an action against us.

NATHAN HARRIS . I have been book-keeper to Mr. Bennett for many years—this bill is my writing—I make out all the bills—Mrs. Bennett knows nothing about them—this receipt to it is the prisoner's writing—on Sunday, the 10th of Aug., I went to the prosecutor's books, as I do every Sunday—no one writes in the ledger but myself—here is the com
mon waste book, and everything that occurs is entered in this—here is another book, in which the entry is made from that common waste-book, and in this it is entered 5l., in the prisoner's writing—this is for me to enter into the ledger—this is 5l. only, but no shillings; that led to tne finding it out—here is, "Hay paid bill, 5l."
JURY. Q. If you had got the 5l., you would have been 7s. short? A. Yes—that caused the finding it out—I said it must have been 5l. 7s., and then it was only 4l. 7s.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. What did you do then? A. I went to Mr. Hay, to know what had been paid, and then the prisoner said to me, "Don't say anything to mistress about it; I will try and make it up by next Sunday, and then the books will be all right"—he said he was sorry for it.

Cross-examined. Q. Will you swear that this 5l. is the prisoner's writing? A. Decidedly—if it had been entered 5l. 7s., I should not have discovered it—I should have taken it for granted that the money had been paid.

SIMON BENNETT . I am the prosecutor's son—he is on the Continent—in consequence of what I heard from Harris, I had some conversation with the prisoner—I asked him what he had received from Mr. Hay—he said, "A cheque for 11l. 5s."—I said "How much did you give my mother?" he said 4l. 7s., and he gave Mr. Hay's man 5l. 18s.—I said, "How much do you make that?"—he said, "11l. 5s."—I said, "How do you make that out? it is only 10l. 5s."—he did not know what to say—he seemed very much confused, and did not seem to know how to account for the other 1l.—his father was going by—I called him in and told him of it—he said, "I am very sorry, Mr. Bennett, but I am not surprised at it; he is a very bad boy; I could have got him into the Post Office"—the prisoner said he did not know how to account for the 1l.; he must have lost it, and had reckoned it up wrong—I said I did not know what to do in it myself, as my father was on the Continent, and I was not in the business—I consulted with Mr. Harris, and we sent the prisoner away—next morning he entered an action against us—I believe the action was not brought by the prisoner's present attorney—I do not know.

JAMES LEWIS (police-constable L 36). I apprehended the prisoner on the 11th of Aug.—he was given into custody by Harris—he said it was no use, he intended to bring an action against him. On the following day, in going to the police-office, he was met by an acquaintance of his own, who asked him what he had been doing, that he was locked up—he said Bennett's people had locked him up last night—he told him to go and get a solicitor—when he got a little farther, he met another person, who asked him what he was locked up for—he said he had made a mistake in a sovereign, and Bennett's people had locked him up.
NOT GUILTY .

2164.
ELLEN LAVIE was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining 2 half-crowns by false pretences.

SUSANNAH HARRIET TAPSON . I am the wife of John Tapson, a sur
geon, living at Clapham
rise—on the 10th of June, about half-past one o'clock, I saw the prisoner at my house—Mr. Tapson was from home—she said, "I am unknown to you, but well known to Mr. Tapson, who is well known to myself and my family; he has attended me and my family"—she said she was unfortunately situated with a street cab, and she had left home without her purse—I asked her what she required—she said 5s. would be sufficient—I then save her two half-crowns, believing her to be a patient of my husband's, who, she said, had attended herself and family—she said she had been attended by my husband—I asked her to leave her name—she said she had no card, but would write her name—she wrote it, but I have destroyed it—she wrote, "Miss Evans, Grove House, Leyton, Essex"—I immediately replied, "I thought your name was Edwards"—she said, "No,

Evans is my name—Miss Evans"—she said she would return and leave it in two days—I begged she would call before eleven or after two o'clock, that she might see Mr. Tapson—she said she knew those were his hours, she knew him very well—she then left, and I did not see her again till she was in custody.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you sure you gave her two half-crowns? A. Yes, two half-crown pieces.
JOHN TAPSON . I am the husband of the last witness—I know nothing of the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. How long hare you been in business in Clapham? A. Between four and five years—I succeeded to a practice previous to that, and before that I had been in the hospital—I can say that I never attended the prisoner—I should remember the face of every person I attended—I attend all my cases myself—if I have been obliged to send an assistant I have known the cases he has seen—I will undertake to say that I know every person I hate attended both in the hospital and out of it—I have been in practice about ten years from the time I went into the hospital—I cannot speak to the number of patients I have attended—I think not so many as 200 or 800 a year—I will undertake to say I remember all those to a sufficient extent to know that I never attended the prisoner—I cannot tell you that the prisoner has a particular eye or a particular note by which I know that I have not attended her, but if I had attended you I should remember it—I have patients of the name of Edwards and Evans—I know them perfectly—I have not looked through my books with reference to this case—I had my attention called to the prisoner for the first time when she was at the police court—Mr. Saunders had my business before me.
COURT. Q. You are able to swear that the prisoner was not a patient of yours? A. That she was not a patient, or ever bad been.
RICHARD COVER (police-constable P 88.) I apprehended the prisoner on the 3rd Oct. on another charge.

GUILTY —
Confined Six Months.
(There were two other charges against the prisoner.)

2165.
BENJAMIN HENRY HOLYOAK was indicted
for stealing 6 planes, value 1l. 15s.; 3 saws, 15s.; and 1 stock, 15s.; the goods of
William Ingliss; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM INGLISS . I am a carpenter, in the employ of Mr. Young, of West-square, St. Georges's. On the 2nd of Sept. I was working at a building in New-street, Bermondsey New-road—I went away to dinner at twelve o'clock, leaving my tools lying about—there were three baskets there, one of which was mine, but the tools were not in it—after I bad been away about half an hour, Green called us out of a public-house—I went back with him, and found the greater part of my tools in the basket, and in charge of Ashworth—there were six planes, a stock, and three saws—they were worth about 3l. altogether—they are here—I never knew the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Were there a great number of tools scattered about? A. Yes—all that were in the basket were not mine—there were a few besides mine—there were three carpenters at work there

CHARLES GREEN . I am a labourer, and live in Blackfriars-row. on the 2nd of Sept. I was employed by Mr. Young at the buildmg—I re
member

the men going to dinner—I remained outside to have an eye to the bricklayers' tools—the prisoner was not employed there, but I saw him come round to the corner of the building where I sat having my dinner—I merely saw his face—I did not see whether he had anything or not—he said to me, "Where are the carpenters gone to dinner who work at this building?"—I said, "I do not know"—he walked off to the front of the building—in a few minutes I thought he had no business round there, as it was not a public thoroughfare, and I jumped up, took my dinner in my hand, and went round to the front of the building—in consequence of what a woman told me I followed the prisoner, and overtook him with the basket of tools on his back—I said, "Where are you going with these tools, mate?"—he said, "I am going to a fresh job"—I said, "I am Yery much mistaken if you have not taken these from our building"—he laid, "God bless you! I will go back with you"—he did so—I unlocked the back door—he went into the building and put the tools down—Mr. Ashworth said to me, "Is it the men's tools he has got?"—I said, "I do not know, he seems to say they are his own"—"They are my own," the prisoner said—I said to Mr. Ashworth, "Do you know how many baskets the carpenters have got?"—he said, "Three large ones, and one small one"—I went into every room, and could only find two large ones and one small one—I said to the prisoner, "You had better stop till the men come from dinner"—he said, "I shall lose my job; I know where the men go to dinner; I will go and make it all right that they are mine"—he then left the tools in the building and said to Mr. Ashworth, "I will leave my tools in your charge while I go to the men, to satisfy them that the tools are mine"—the prisoner and I then walked off to the Com
passes, where the men dine—when we got nearly there he said, "You go in and tell the men to come out"—I said, "You had better come in with me"—he went with me. very near to the door, and took a pipe out of his pocket—he said, "Go in and tell them to come out"—I left him out
side and went in, tapped the prosecutor on the shoulder, and said, "I want you"—I then went out, and the prisoner was gone—I am quite cer
tain he is the man—he was dressed in a white flannel jacket.

Cross-examined. Q. You had not seen him before? A. Never—I saw him again when I was sent for on the Monday following—this oc
curred on Tuesday, the 2nd of Sept.—I merely saw his face when I first saw him—I could not tell whether he had anything on his back or not—I cannot exactly say what room the carpenters' tools were in—I did not know what was in the basket till I got up to him—I did not examine them—I do not know that they were the same that were in the basket when I came back—the prisoner did not offer me anything to drink or smoke—the house where the men got their dinner might be three or four minute's walk from the building—the prisoner and I walked there side by side—Robert Everett was one of the carpenters—the name of the other I do not know—those men are at work there still—the prisoner did not tell me he had been sent for some carpenter's tools—he said the tools were his—I said, "The prisoner seems to say they are his," and he assented to it—when I saw him at the police-office it was not on this charge.

ROBERT ASHWORTH . I am a hatter, and live in Brook-street, Ber
mondsey New-road. On Tuesday, the 2nd of Oct, between twelve and one o'clock, my wife told me something, and I went to the building—I saw the prisoner and Green—the prisoner had a basket of carpenter's

tools on his back—there was some talk between us about these tools—the prisoner left them in my charge, and said he would go with Green and make it all right—I took charge of them till Green and the carpenters came back—the prisoner did not come back—I showed Ingliss the same tools and the basket—I had had charge of them all the time.

Cross-examined. Q. When you came in was the basket lying down? A. No; the prisoner had it on his back, and Green was with him in the front part of the building—Green said the prisoner seemed to say that the tools were his own; and the prisoner said they were his, and he was come to look for a job—the conversation occupied from five till, I suppose, ten minutes—I never saw the prisoner before—I saw him at the station-house nearly a fortnight afterwards—I swear he is the person.

MART EVANS . I am the wife of Evan Evans, a tanner—I saw the prisoner between twelve and one o'clock on the 2nd of Sept from the back part of the building with a basket on his shoulder—I called out to a bricklayer's labourer on the premises—he went after the prisoner—I saw him overtake him, and bring him back—I am sure he is the person.

Cross-examined. Q. How far was he from you? A. I was at my gate—he came from the back of the building, and came towards me—he had passed me before he was brought back—the nearest point at which he had passed me was twenty yards, or perhaps more—I saw him when he came back with the basket.

ROBERT ASH WORTH
re-examined. This is the basket which the pri
soner had on his back, and these are the tools—I kept them till Ingliss came.

WILLIAM INGLISS
re-examined. These tools are mine—here are planes, saws, and a stock.

JOHN BARKER (police-constable K 108.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at Clerkenwell—(read—Convicted 20th May, 1845, and confined three months)—I was at the trial—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

2166.
DANIEL WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 4l.; 1 waistcoat, 18s.; and 1 pair, of trousers, 1l. 16s.; the goods of
James Charles Edmiston and another.

GEORGE HOBDAY . I am partner with James Charles Edmiston—we are tailors, and live in Gracechurch-street—the prisoner came to our shop about the 30th of Sept.—I do not recollect seeing him before that day—he said, "I want a suit of black; my name is Williams, 43, Mincing-lane; you have done something for me before"—I said, "I recollect the name, but not the face"—I took his instructions for making a suit of black, and asked the day it was to go home—he said on Friday, at four o'clock—he asked the price; I said, "4l. the coat, 18s. the waistcoat, and 1l. 16s. the trousers"—he said, "What will that be?"—I said, "6l. 14s., but I suppose 6l. 10s. will do for cash"—he said it was for cash—the clothes were made, and sent by our shopman, Charles Hemmings—he returned, but brought back nothing except the change which had been given him to take with the things—I saw the prisoner afterwards at the Lambeth police-station.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. He called your attention to a transaction you had had with him some time before? A. Yes—I

recollect it—it was a ready money transaction—he fetched the article, and paid 16s. for it—that was the transaction he reminded me of—he said, "My name is Williams, 43, Mincing-lane;" and he went on to say, "That is our place of business, but you had better send to my private address," and I did so—our shopman went to 43, Mincing-lane—I have ascertained there is a place of business there conducted by the prisoner's father, but the father said he had not been there for five months—the clothes were sent back a fortnight afterwards, on the day on which we ap
peared before Mr. Henry—that was not within three days of the transaction—there was a remand for a week—the prisoner had the clothes on in court, to the Magistrate's surprise—Charles Hemmings has been in our employ for twelve months.

JAMES CHARLES EDMISTON . I am in partnership with Mr. Hobday. I only knew of this order from the order-book—I sent the clothes home by our shopman—I gave him particular instructions not to leave them without the money—there was a black coat, waistcoat, and trowsers—I gave the shopman change for a 10l. note—he came back about half-past five o'clock, and stated he had left the clothes—I went with him to the address immediately—I took a policeman with me, and went in a cab—I did not find the prisoner—I went again on Saturday morning—I did not find the prisoner then—I then went to the police-office, and asked the Ma
gistrate's advice—I did not see the prisoner till he was in custody—I had never seen him before.

Cross-examined. Q. When your shopman came back without either clothes or money, you were very angry with him? A. No, I was not angry, nor quite pleased—I did not tell him that unless the money was got he should go out of my service—I never used any threat of that kind—I did not tell him I would not keep him—I did not give him warning—I did not say anything about the clothes, except that we were to go back and endeavour to find the man—I did not go or send to Mincing-lane before we supplied the clothes—the prisoner had said he lived in Dorey-street—I certainly went there that evening with the cab—I did not see Mr. Matthews that night—I went again the next morning—I did not see Mr. Matthews then—I saw him at St. Martin's workhouse—he was holding some office in the parish, and was landlord of the house where the prisoner was living—he said he considered the prisoner was perfectly respectable—I inquired if he had absconded, and Mr. Matthews said he had slept at home every night—I inquired about his employment—it is quite possible that Mr. Matthews said, "I have no doubt he will pay you, if you wait a day or two"—I do not recollect it now—if I said so at the Police-court, it was true—I do not recollect that I said in answer to that, "Very well, I will"—I will not swear I did not say so—I said, "I will endeavour to see you again before I take harsh measures"—I said that because I would not frighten the man away from his lodging, but with the intention of taking him into custody—I should not have taken him into custody if I had been paid.

Q. If Mr. Matthews had paid you the money on that occasion, would you or would you not have given the prisoner into custody? A. Certainly I should—I should not have taken the money from Mr. Matthews—if I said, "Very well, I will wait," it was a subterfuge, and I was telling a lie, be
cause I would not frighten the man away—I went to Mr. Matthews to

ascertain if he was a respectable man, as I doubted whether the house was respectable—I wished to discover every little testimony I could—I did not go to Mincing-lane—it struck me I might have got some information there, but if I had gone there I might have been in the situation of com
pounding a felony—when I called at Dorey-street I did not see Mrs. Mat
thews—I saw two or three women—I saw a woman whom I have since ascertained to be Mrs. Matthews—I do not know that I saw this lady—(looking at Mrs. Matthews)—I swear I had not a long conversation with her—I have no recollection of her face at all—I believe it was a boy opened the door to me—I saw three women there—I asked if Mr. Williams was at home—one of the women did not say no, but she expected him in shortly—if that had been said I should have waited—I think the boy asked me to walk in and sit down—I had a policeman with me in uniform.

CHARLES HEMMINGS . I am shopman to the prosecutor. I saw the pri
soner come into the shop—I did not hear the bargain about the clothes—I was sent home with the clothes—I was to take them home, and not leave them without the money—when I got to Dorey-street I did not find the prisoner—I was told to wait—I found the prisoner did live there—I waited about twenty minutes—it was about five o'clock when I got there—the prisoner came in, and asked if I came from Mr. Edmiston—I said I did—he said, "You have brought my clothes, have you?"—I said, "Yes"—he said he would go up stairs and put them on—he took them from me and went up stairs—he came down, and had them on—he asked me if there could be any alteration made in the breast of the coat—I said it could, but it was not usual in that kind of coat—he then looked down, and said they would do very well—he said, "I have just come from Mr. Ed
miston and have settled for them, and he sent word you are to leave them"—he said he had made an arrangement if there was any alteration wanted to have it done on Tuesday—I said I had got the bill and was told to bring back the money, I did not know what to do—I said, "Have you any
thing to show?"—he said it was all right, and he would call and let Mr. Edmiston see them on.

cross-examined. Q. When you got home whom did you see? A. Mr. Hobday and Mr. Edmiston were in the shop—Mr. Edmiston was very angry with me for having left the clothes—he did not swear at me—he did not tell me he should not keep me in his service—he did not give me warning—he exclaimed he was robbed—he and Mr. Hobday were very angry—I am still in the place, and have had had no warning to quit—I do not know that I have any reason to expect to be turned away—Mrs. Matthews was not present at the time I had the conversation with the pri
soner about the clothes—there was no woman at all in the room—I could not tell whether Mrs. Mathews wai in the adjoining room—I can tell every word that the prisoner said when he came down stairs—I know what he said, and the place in wnich every word stood, without the alteration of a word.

HENRY NOLAN (police-constable L 129.) The prisoner was given into my custody on the 6th of Oct. by Hemmings—the prisoner wanted him to go into the City with him, and said be would settle with him—he would not—he said he was afraid he would make his escape.
MRS. MATTHEWS. I am the wife of Samuel Matthews, who it relieving

overseer of the parish of St. Martin-in-the-field—the prisoner has lodged at our house about four or five months—I have not the slightest fault to find with him—he has been a decent, and, as far as I have seen, an honest young man—I remember some clothes being brought home on the 3rd of Oct. by Hemmings—I opened the door, and asked him to come in and wait—the prisoner came home soon afterwards—I left the room instantly, and went into the next room—I could hear every word that passed—I re
collect the prisoner coming down with the clothes on—he made great complaints about the coat not fitting him on the breast—I considered it was the coat by his saying the breast, and he said he would call and make arrangement with Mr. Edmiston on Tuesday about the alteration—he did not say, in my hearing, that he had been to Mr. Edmiston's, and that it was all right—I heard all that passed till within a minute, when I left the room, went to the back-door, and then the street-door shut—the prisoner did not say he had been to Mr. Edmiston's—he said he would go to him—Hemmings did not object to that in my hearing—I did not hear him speak at all—the prisoner has been at my house and slept there every night—he has generally been in about ten o'clock at night—he was there to be found then, and at eight o'clock in the morning—he always paid his lodging regularly.
COURT. Q. You say you were away from the next room? A. Yes, about a minute.
MR. EDMISTON. Will you ask the witness who paid the rent to her? Witness. The prisoner never paid it at all, his father paid it.
MR. BALLANTINE (to the witness). Q. Did you always get your rent? A. Yes—I know the prisoner's father—he is a coffee-broker, in Mincing-lane—I should consider he is a respectable man.
NOT GUILTY .

2167.
MATILDA PALMER was indicted
for stealing 1 diamond, value 8s.; 1 ruby, 7s.; 1 purse, 1s.; and 4 shillings; the goods and monies of
Thomas Gardner, from his person.

THOMAS GARDNER . I am an oilman, and live at Camberwell. On the 21st of Oct., I was in the New Kent-road—the prisoner accosted me—I have no doubt she is the person—I did not want to say anything to her—she put her arms round me, and I felt her hands in each of my trowsers' pockets—I had a frock coat on, but it was open—she took her hands out of my pockets and ran away—I directly felt that she had taken my purse out—I caught her shawl, and said, "Stop a minute"—she ran off, and left her shawl in my hand—I hallooed out, and two gentlemen and a policeman came up—I had in my pocket a diamond, a ruby, and a purse with 4s. in it—my trowsers were rather low down.
Prisoner. I declare I never saw him; I had been washing all day; I was never out of the house all day; I never had such a shawl in my life.

JOHN DAVID STEADMAN . I am a policeman. I was on duty about two o'clock that morning—I had seen the prisoner on the road several times that night previously, and about two minutes before the robbery, I saw her speak to the prosecutor—I went on about forty yards—I then saw her run down Lyon-street, and saw the prosecutor with this shawl lying at his feet—I know the shawl—I had seen the prisoner wearing it often, and had seen it on her not two minutes before—I went to her
house and took her—she denied the robbery, and denied knowing the shawl—I had seen her six or seven times that evening.
Prisoner. As to your seeing me that evening, you might have seen me at eight o'clock; not afterwards.

GUILTY .* Aged 19.—
Confined Nine Months.

2167.
THOMAS FOUNTAIN was indicted
for stealing 1 handker-chief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Parlet Patrick, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

PARLET PATRICK . I live in York-street, York-road, Lambeth. On the 12th of Oct, I was walking with my wife in York-road, about a quarter past nine o'clock—the prisoner came behind me very close, and I made room for him to pass—he did not pass, but turned round and walked the other way—after I had walked about twenty yards farther, he came behind me again—I then had my thoughts about me—I looked over my shoulder, and he had got hold of my coat—I turned, and caught him—I said, "Young man, stop"—he ran off—I ran after him, down Sutton-street, calling, "Stop thief!" there were some men at the end—the pri
soner then sung out "Stop him!"—I said, "That is him," and they stopped him—he threw open his coat, and said, "I have got nothing of yours"—the policeman then came and took him—he searched, and found nothing—he said, "We will go back"—he found my handkerchief about ten yards from where the prisoner first ran from—a little boy had picked it up—it is mine, and I had lost it from my pocket.
Prisoner. Q. Can you swear I am the man? A. Yes—I never lost sight of you—I did not see you pick my pocket, or throw the handker-chief away—I did not see it in your possession, nor find it on you.

EDWARD O'HARA . I heard a cr'y of "Stop thief!"—I ran out of No. 30, Sutton-street, and saw the prisoner running—I followed him—I did not see anything thrown away—in coming back I picked up a pocket handkerchief.

PARLET PATRICK
re-examined. The prisoner had run by the place where the handkerchief was found.
JAMES SARTAIN (police-constable L 101.) I took the prisoner—when I had him in custody, the handkerchief was handed to me, on the same side of the way.

Prisoner. I was going along, and turned down Sutton-street; a young man rushed by me with great force; I heard a cry of "Stop thief!" I cried too, and the roan stopped me; I said, "I have got nothing;" I can assure you I am quite innnocent.

EDWARD O'HARA
re-examined. Q. Who was running first? A. The prisoner—I was in front of the mob—I saw them coming up—they passed me—I did not hear the prisoner cry." Stop thief!"—I heard the prose
cutor.

JAMES BROOK (policeman.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, at Newington—(read—Convicted 21th July, 1844)—he was confined one year, because he used great violence when taken—he is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2168.
HENRY MARKS was indicted
for stealing 9 1/2 yards of printed cotton, value 5s., the goods of
William Buddry Elsden; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY SPARLING . I am shopman to William Buddry Elsden, of Bruns
wick-place, Old Kent-road. On the 30th of Sept. this piece of printed cotton was safe in the shop at ten minutes past eight o'clock—it was missed at half-past eight—I am quite sure this is it—it is my master's.

WILLIAM NOAKES (police-constable M 104.) On the evening of the 30th of Sept., at twenty minutes past eight o'clock, I stopped the prisoner about 300 yards from the prosecutor's—I asked what he had got—he said, "Nothing"—I opened his coat, and found this cotton under it—I said, "Do you call this nothing?"—he said, "That is what I just picked up."
Prisoner. I picked it up against the Railway station.

GEORGE WILDE (police-constable M 94.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, at the Surrey Sessions—(read—Convicted 26th May, 1845; confined one month, and whipped)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

2169.
MARGARET ROBERTS was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 2l.; and 1 pair of ear-rings, 5s.; the goods of
Ann Naylor, her mistress.

ANN NAYLOR . I am a widow. The prisoner was my charwoman—about the 27th of Sept. I was moving some goods, and missed a watch—I afterwards missed some other things—the watch has not been found—she said she had not seen it—here are some other things which are mine, but they are not in this indictment.

HENRY NIXON (police-constable L 85.) I was called by the prosecutrix, and went after the prisoner—I asked if she knew anything of the watch—she said she did not—I took her to the station, and asked if she lodged at the house where I heard she did—she said, "No"—I searched there, and found thirty-eight duplicates—a bread
tray, a looking-glass, and copper, were given me by Mrs. Reed—she is not here.
Prisoner. The duplicates under the bed were of my own property.
NOT GUILTY .

2170.
MARGARET ROBERTS was again indicted
for stealing 3 quilts, value 6s.; 3 yards of crape, 1s.; 1 pair of snuffers and tray, 2s.; and 1 table-cloth, 3s.; the goods of
Ann Naylor, her mistress.
ANN NAYLOR . About the 20th of Jan. I missed some quilts, crape, snuffers, table-cloth, and other things—this quilt, and these other things, are mine—the prisoner was living with me as charwoman.

Prisoner. The two shifts belong tome. Witness. No, they are mine—I examined them at the pawnbroker's—I have no doubt about this counter-pane—these towels are mine—they are not marked, but I have some simi
lar to them—the shirt is my son's—it is marked.
HENRY NIXON (police-constable L 85.) I found the duplicates of the sheet and counterpane under the prisoner's bed, with other duplicates.
CHRISTOPHER DRY . I am assistant to a pawnbroker—I have the sheet and counterpane, which were pawned, I believe, by the prisoner—this is the duplicate given for them.
Prisoner. The prosecutrix was moving, to deprive the landlord of his rent; the shifts belong to me; the knives are mine, and one table-cloth; she allowed me to pawn some things.

ANN NAYLOR
re-examined. I never allowed her to pawn this sheet or table-cloth—she never pawned but once in her life for me.

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Four Months.

2171.
WILLIAM MALEY was indicted
for stealing 1 sovereign, 1 shil
ling, and 1 sixpence; the monies of
Ann Elizabeth Rolfe, from her person; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ANN ELIZABETH ROLFE . I am a servant—I live in Duke's-court, Union-street, Borough—on the 4th of Oct., at half-past eleven o'clock at night, I was standing on the pavement, where there were some people looking at a man—the officer told me something—I put my hand into my pocket and missed a sovereign, a shilling, and a sixpence, which I had had safe not a minute before, wrapped in a small piece of paper—I cannot swear that I saw the prisoner.

ROBERT BRANSFORD (police-constable M 101.) I was on duty in Union-street, in the Borough—I saw the prisoner lift the prosecutrix's dress about a foot from the ground—I saw his hand in her pocket-hole—I watched him—one of his companions told him of it, and he left her—I went and spoke to her, and he disappeared—I took him about an hour afterwards.
Prisoner. I was going home that Saturday night, about eleven o'clock; I passed by a crowd; I was going home again, and the officer came and said I had picked a lady's pocket.

JAMES BOCKHAM (police-sergeant L 37.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at the Surrey Sessions—(read—Convicted 18th March, 1844, confined twenty-one days, solitary)—I know him to be the person—he has been in custody five times besides.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2172.
DAVID ROWELL was indicted
for stealing 1 loaf of bread, value 5d. the goods of
Jonas Rowley, his master, since deceased.

EMILY REBECCA ROWLEY . I resided with my father, Jonas Rowley—he was a baker—I have been accustomed to transact his business—the prisoner was in his employ—I kept an account of what the prisoner deli
vered to Mrs. Freeman—I got the account from the prisoner—I copied it in the waste book, and then it was copied in the day-book—on the 7th of June the prisoner had one quartern loaf for Mrs. Freeman—it used not to be paid for—it was booked—he ought to have delivered that one loaf and he did not.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. You only recollect it from the entry in the book? A. I made the entry in the waste book—my father used to copy it in the ledger, and it is in the ledger now—it is from seeing it in the book that I know I gave it him on the 7th of June—I could not charge my memory with it—the waste books were always de
stroyed as soon as they were filled up and entered in the ledger—I made a great many entries in a day—the account used to be given to me after the prisoner had taken the bread—Mrs. Freeman only had bread twice a week—I went before the Magistrate on this case on the 25th of August—nobody served in my father's shop but him and me—my mother was con
fined.

COURT. Q. Are you able from recollection to say you gave him this one loaf on the 7th of June? A. Yes—Mrs. Freeman had her loaves on Tuesdays and Saturdays—I am able to state that I did, on Saturday the 7th of June, give the prisoner one loaf for her—I never compared the day-book with the waste book, but I can, from my own memory, state I gave him one loaf for her on the 7th of June.
ANN FREEMAN . I dealt with Mr. Rowley for bread—I am sure the
prisoner did not bring me any bread on the 7th of June, because when he did I put it down on a slate.
NOT GUILTY .
(There were three other charges against the prisoner, on which no evidence was offered.)

2173.
MARY BROWN was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Samuel Beale and another.

SAMUEL BEALE . I am in partnership with Mr. Webster; we are pawnbrokers, and live in Great Charlotte-street, Blackfriars. On Saturday night, the 4th of Oct., the prisoner was brought into my shop on a charge, and this pair of shoes was produced—they are mine.

Prisoner. I went to buy a pair, and tried them on; I had one shoe on my foot when the policeman came and took me away; the young man who was going to have the money for them did not come to the Magistrate's on the following Monday; I did not see the prosecutor at the shop.

THOMAS WILLIAM REDFORD (police-constable L 52.) I watched on the prosecutor's premises. I saw the prisoner come up to the front of the shop, take up a pair of shoos, and look round her—she then placed them in her lap—she went past the young man, who was serving a customer with an umbrella—I, thinking she was going off with them, took her, and said, "Where are you going with these shoes?"—she kicked off her shoe and said, "To try them on"—she had got two or three yards from the shop, going away, and had turned away from the shop.

Prisoner's Defence. I had the money in my hand to pay for them; I was trying them on, when the policeman came and took me, before I knew the price; the policeman said I was two yards from the door, which, is false; I was holding my foot up for the young man to put the shoe on.

Witness. No—she had 4s. and some pence screwed up in a paper—she came up with some vegetables and other things in her lap—she placed a cabbage by the side of a post, took the shoes, then took the cabbage up, and was walking clear off—she drew the shoes from her lap, threw them down before her, kicked her shoe off, and commenced fumbling, trying to work her foot into one of the shoes.
NOT GUILTY .

2174.
ROBERT BERRY and
FRANCIS M'CARTHY were in
indicted for
unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which

M'CARTHY pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.—

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant L 8.) I was on duty in Walcot-place, Lambeth, on the 29th of Sept., with Brook—I saw the pri
soners—I had known M'Carthy by sight before—they were going in the direction of Kennington-common—I followed them through the New-road to Denmark-hill, Camberwell—they went down a turning leading to Camberwell-grove—I saw Berry go into a green-grocer's shop—I spoke to the female in the shop, and then followed the prisoners again—they went on to Cambcrwell-grcen, and stopped several minutes, and I saw M'Carthy give something to Berry—they separated, and Berry went into

Mrs. Godfrey's shop, which is a tobacconist's, and M'Carthy waited on the opposite side of the way—Berry came out, joined M'Carthy, and they went down the road—I went into Mrs. Godfrey's shop, and spoke to her—I came out again, and saw the prisoners in company on the opposite side of the way—I followed them to a confectioner's shop between the Green and Camberwell-gate—Berry went in there—when he came out I went in for about a minute—I overtook them again when I got to Wal
worth-road—when they got to Hampton-street they sat down, and waited four or five minutes—Berry then waited at the corner—M'Carthy went down the street, and took up something from the road, and rubbed some
thing between his fingers—he then joined Berry, and gave him what he had rubbed—they went up the road towards the Elephant and Castle-Berry went into Mrs. Cross's shop, and M'Carthy crossed the road to the opposite side—I saw Brook take hold of him, and I went into the shop—as I went in, Berry threw his head back—I thought he was going to swallow something—I took hold of him, and in the struggle I saw this shilling in his hand—I said, "This is a counterfeit shilling"—he said he was going to give 1d. for it—that was for the tobacco that Mrs. Cross was weighing—in going to the station, Brook was on ahead with M'Carthy, and Berry, pointing to M'Carthy, said, "That boy gave me the bad shil
ling"—the shilling I took from Berry had been rubbed with dirt.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Were you on duty? A. Yes, in plain clothes—I did not know Berry—I had been following them nearly three hours—when M'Carthy went down Hampton-street I was opposite the corner of the street—he went ten or twelve paces up the street—I was sometimes fifty yards from them, but when there was anything material to be seen, I got as close to them as I could.

JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118). I was with Goff on the 29th of Sept.—I know Mrs. Bicknell's shop—I saw Berry go into that shop, and M'Carthy was on the opposite side of the way—I was afterwards in the neighbourhood of Mrs. Cross's shop—I secured M'Carthy nearly opposite to it—I found these two counterfeit shillings in his hand, they are bitten and cut—he made a resistance.

LOUISA GODFREY . I am the wife of George Godfrey, a tobacconist, in High-street, Camberwell. On the 29th of Sept, Berry came to the shop for a pennyworth of tobacco—he put down a counterfeit shilling—I took it up, bit it, and said it was not good, and he went away without the tobacco—he said he took the shilling on the Green—this is it—I bit it.
Cross-examined. Q. Which is the bite? A. Here on the edge of it—I did not make this bend on it.

MARY BICKNELL . I keep a tobacconist's shop in Regent-place, Wal
worth-road. Berry came there on the 29th of Sept for a pennyworth of tobacco—he offered me a shilling—I took it in my hand and cut two pieces out of it—this is it—I did not take it—he said I ought not to have done that, as he had just taken it down the road—he left the shop with it.

ELIZABETH CROSS . I am the wife of James Cross, a tobacconist, in Cumberland-row, Walworth-road. On the 29th of Sept. Berry came for a pennyworth of tobacco—he had not time to pay for it, as Mr. Goff rushed in and seized him.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF
re-examined. This is the shilling I got out of Berry's hand at Mrs. Cross's.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These three shillings are all counterfeit, and made of the same metal throughout—to my best opinion they are all cast in the same mould.
(Berry received a good character.)

BERRY—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Three Months.

2175.
WILLIAM BAINES and
WILLIAM REYNOLDS were in
dicted for
a like offence.

LOUISA JULIAN . I keep a tobacconist's shop. On the 22nd of Sept. Baines came in for a pennyworth of tobacco—I served him with it—he paid me with a 4d. piece—I did not look particularly at it—I had looked at the till shortly before—I had no silver but a shilling in it—as Baines stepped out the policeman stepped in, and in a hurried manner said, "What did that man pay in?"—I said, "A groat"—my son went and took it out of the till, bit it, and gave it to him.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How did you put the 4d. piece in the till? A. I opened the till and put it in—I saw there was only 1s. in it—I examined it in one minute afterwards.

JOHN JULIAN . I am the son of Louisa Julian. I came into the shop directly Baines went out—the officer came in—I took the 4d. piece out of the till and bit it, and handed it to him—there was only 1s. in the till besides.

SARAH AITKIN . I am the wife of Charles Aitkin. We live in Great Suffolk-street, in the Borough—on the 22nd of Sept. Reynolds came into our shop for a 1d. saveloy—he paid me with 4d. piece—I put it into the till—the officer came in—I took it out and gave it him—I had no other silver in the till.
Reynolds. Q. Did you give me the change? A. I laid it on the counter—I do not know whether you had it.

JOHN WARD . I am barman at the Red Lion public-house at the corner of Great Sutton-street, Southwark. On the 22nd of Sept., about eight o'clock, Baines came in for half a pint of porter—he laid down a bad 4d., piece—I bit it double, and very nearly broke it into two pieces—I returned it to him—he walked out with it, and left the beer on the counter.
Cross-examined. Q. How long was he in the shop? A. A minute or two—there were two or three other customers.

JOHN WHITLAM (police-constable M 89.) I was on duty in the Old Kent-road in plain clothes with West—I saw the prisoners in the act of leaving the Kent-road and proceeding towards the Dover-road with ano
ther person—I saw Reynolds go to a grocer's shop—I followed them through the Dover-road to the Red Lion—Baines went in there—I saw him come out and join Reynolds and the other—they proceeded along Suffolk-street to the Windsor Castle—Baines went into Julian's shop, and Reynolds into the Windsor Castle—he came out in about a minute—Baines came out of Julian's shop, and I saw him put his right hand up to his hat twice, which I considered was a signal—they then joined company, and all proceeded to Aitkin's shop—Reynolds went in there—Baines and the other went on, and stood conversing at the corner of a dark turn
ing—Baines then left the other, and passed and repassed Aitkin's shop—I took him into custody—I fouud upon him at the station a good sixpence—I
produce a 4d. piece which I received from John Julian—I saw him take it out of the till.

THOMAS WEST (police-constable M 249.) I was with Whitlam—I saw Reynolds go into Aitkin's shop—I followed him, inside—Baines had just passed—I could not see him when I was inside—I saw Reynolds take a 4d. piece from his pocket, and put it on the counter—I told Mrs. Aitkin I thought it was had—she said she thought it was good—I said I was an officer, and I asked Reynolds if it was a bad one—Mrs. Aitkin took it and marked it, and gave it to me—Reynolds asked if there was no more money in the till—she took it out, and showed him there was no more—this is the 4d. piece.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit, and made of Britannia metal.
Baines. Mrs. Julian says I was in her shop, and had tobacco and change: I was taken soon after, and what could I have done with the tobacco or change?

BAINES—
GUILTY
of uttering to Julian.—
Confined Six Months.

REYNOLDS*—
GUILTY
of uttering to Aitkin.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2176.
WILLIAM PARSONS was indicted
for a like offence; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

2177.
JANE JURY was indicted
for stealing 3 3/4 yards of linen cloth, value 9s.; 5 handkerchiefs, 3s.; 3 blankets, 15s.; and 76 yards of calico, 1l. 6s.; the goods of
Thomas Shaw, her master.

RICHARD ROGERS . I am shopman to Thomas Shaw, linen-draper, High-street, Southwark—the prisoner was his cook.
