On the 18th of Oct., about ten o'clock at night, I went to the room occupied by myself—there is a spare bed in that room—as I went up stairs, I heard a rustling noise—I went into my room—there was no candle there, but I had one in my hand—I looked under the spare bed and saw the prisoner, and under the other bed I saw two parcels—I asked the prisoner who the first parcel belonged to—she said, to herself, and the other to Mrs. Cornelius—I opened the first parcel, and in it were three blankets, the property of my employer—I separated one of them from the other—it was one of a pair, of which I had sold one the day previous—in the other bundle I found fifty-three yards of calico, which was my employer's, and had his mark on—I then, with the officer, searched the prisoner's box, and found five cambric handkerchiefs, a length of lawn, and a piece or two of calico, which were my employer's, and had our private mark on them—these articles had not been sold—the prisoner was to have left on the Monday following.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Who is Mrs. Cornelius? A. A friend of the prisoner's, who came to the house occasionally.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Year.

2178.
ELLEN CONNOLLY was indicted
for stealing 1 printed book, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Shaw; and 10 yards of calico, 4s., the goods of
Thomas Shaw, her master.

WILLIAM SHAW . I am the son of Thomas Shaw—lie is a linen-draper—the prisoner was his housemaid. On Saturday night, the 18th of Oct., I, with a policeman, searched the prisoner's box—she was not present, but the policeman was, and Mr. Rogers—believe it was the prisoner's box—it was in a room adjoining her room, which is merely used to hold boxes and a chest of drawers—I found in the bottom of the box this book, which is mine—I also found three lengths of new calico, containing about ten yards—it was my father's, and had our private mark on it—I had missed my book about a month.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I suppose the mark was on all the calico you sold? A. Yes—we have not had any young men left lately—the last who left was Mr. Thomas, about six months ago—he might have sold this calico—this is my book—the last time I saw it it was in the bookcase.
MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Has any other person left since the calico was in the stock? A. No—this was in the stock when Thomas left.

WILLIAM GRIST (police-constable M 223). I was called in to Mr. Shaw's on the 18th of Oct.—after I took the prisoner to the station, I searched a box—I had asked her in the station for her keys—she said she had thrown them into a drawer—I found a chest of drawers in the lobby, where the boxes were—I found four keys in one drawer—I tried one to a box, and it opened it—found the book and the calico—the prisoner was in the station on the other charge—(see page 1033, No. 2177) the bookcase from which this book was taken was merely open shelves.

WILLIAM SHAW
re-examine. Q. What was the cost of this book? A. I cannot remember—I had not left it about that anybody might have taken and read it—I had left it on the shelves.
WILLIAM ROGERS . I saw the box searched—it was the prisoner's—I know it from the position in which it was placed, and I had seen her locking and unlocking it.

Cross-examined. Q. How could you see the maid at her box? A. Our warehouse was opposite the room door, and I had to pass it several times a day—I do not know of her having bought any calico—the servants have bought things, I believe.

COURT to WILLIAM SHAW. Q. Where do you keep the calico? A. The lengths that are cut are below—the maids have to pass through there to fetch coals—these are each a fag end, and have our marks on—the prisoner had been a year and three-quarters or two years in my father's service, and was going away in consequence of our missing some spirits.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Three Months.

2179.
OWEN KEEFE and
JOSEPH BRYAN were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the property of
William James Con
stable.

WILLIAM CONSTABLE . I live in Cherry Garden-street, Bermondsey. I was in Tooley-street one Wednesday night, in Sept., between eight and nine o'clock—in consequence of information I felt in my pocket, and missed my handkerchief, which I had used about a quarter of an hour before—this is it.
GEORGE ELLERY . I have lived in Burnham-street, Tooley-street, and I

am a ticket collector at the railway. On the evening of the 24th of Sept., I was at the top of Tooley-street—I had been speaking to the prosecutor, and saw the prisoners go behind him—I had not noticed a handkerchief in Keefe's hand previous to his going there, but I saw him after he went there hand a handkerchief to Bryan, which Bryan made his escape with.

Q. That is just the reverse of what you said before? A. I might make a mistake in the names—I had not seen either of them before—they were both stopped—Bryan threw down the handkerchief; I took it up and gave it to Jones.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. What time in the morning did you go to the police-office? A. It might be between twelve and one—I heard the names of the parties—I pointed out the person that I point out now, as having taken the handkerchief—it might be a mistake in the name—I think there were three boys beside the prisoners stood round—I cannot say how far Keefe went—Bryan went about nine or ten yards—I did not actually see Keefe take the handkerchief—I saw it in his hand—my deposition was read over to me, and I signed it.

Q. You say here, "I saw Bryan take a handkerchief from Mr. Con
stable's pocket" A. I did not say "candidly" that I saw him take it out of his pocket—he might have picked it up certainly—the prisoners might be a yard from the prosecutor when I first saw the handkerchief—neither of them were in front of him—I was standing looking straight it the pri
soners—their backs were to me—I am positive one prisoner had it, and banded it to the other, who ran away.
EVAN JONES (police-constable M 250). I produce this handkerchief, which I received from Ellary.

COURT to the Prosecutor. Q. What is your name? A. William James Constable—I said my name was William—it is—I heard from my father and mother that it was James—I go by the name of William James amongst my family.
Bryan. Mr. Taylor asked him three times if it was me took it, and he said it was me.

COURT to the Prosecutor. Q. Did that pass? A. No, I believe not—I have no recollection of it—Bryan was stopped by a man named Tay
lor, who is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

2180.
BENJAMIN CRUSSELL was indicted
for stealing 3 pieces of iron, called weights, value 5s.; 50 knives, 30s.; 2 pairs of bellows, 5s.; 6 benches, 3l.; 1 vice, 10s.; 1 lathe-wheel, 2l.; 1 case for a beer-engine, 2l.; and a grindstone, 2s.; the goods of
Charles Rice; and 2 iron melting-pans, 30s.; and an iron furnace and chimney, 20s.; the goods of Cbarles Rice, and fixed to a certain building.
MESSRS. BALLANTINE and BALDWIN conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLES RICE . I have been in business in the Borough for forty-fivs years, but I have now left it to my son—I am the owner of a house, No. 45, Roebuck-place, Dover-road, which I let to the prisoner at Lady
day last, at the rent of 45l. a year—there was a detached building across the yard of that house, and that I was to let at 5l. a year—I did not let that to the prisoner at all—I had a furnace and chimney and some other things

of mine in that building—some were fixed, and some moveable—they were to be kept in these back premises in case I should let the place to a pew
terer—they were left there in consequence of the prisoner opening the house as a beer-shop—if that did not answer, I was to keep all these tools and utensils, thinking I might let it to a person in the same line again as it had been before—I did not tell the prisoner what he was to do with them—he was not to sell or dispose of them—they were to be left there as belonging to me, in case I should let the house, if his shop did not answer—I gave him no control or power over them at all—nothing was said about finding a purchaser—no authority was given to him in case any one should apply to him, to do anything—I said if any one came after the things, or wanted them, the person was to be sent to me—there was no other authority given by me to him, and the building was not let to him—I was to have 5l. a year more if that was let, and I moved everything out of the shop to that—I considered the goods perfectly safe—in about two or three months I missed some of them—I made some inquiries, I think of the prisoner's wife—the prisoner remained my tenant in that house up to the second quarter-day, up to Michaelmas—he went away in the night—he gave me no notice of his leaving—he was gone on the quarter-day, and everything was cleared away—he did not, on or about the 8th of May, or between that and Michaelmas, tell me he had sold these goods, or anything of that sort—he did not pay me any rent.
JURY. Q. Was there any written agreement between you? Not that I know of—I cannot recollect signing any.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Was this adjoining bulding in the yard of the premises? A. Yes, across the yard—there is a wall going round—it is a warehouse built at the end of the gardens—there is a lock upon it—I had the key of it in the first instance, but the prisoner asked for it, and then he had the key—I think he had the key soon after he had the place—he wanted to put some things into it—I did not allow him to use any of these articles—he was to take care that they were not taken away—he was in possession for my use, and to take care that no person took them away.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. After this house had been let to the prisoner, was any application made for the key of this out-house? A. Not that I recollect—the key was delivered to the prisoner some short time afterwards—he said to me that he wanted to put some things into it, and I banded him the key, believing he wanted to put some things in—I found two crates there of his—I did not miss the furnace nor the brick-work till after he was gone.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Was it after you had given him the key that you told him he was to keep these things for your use and not for his own? A. I never told him anything of the kind—they were to be taken care of in case I should let it to a pewterer again—there was no one in the house but him—they were certainly not to be taken care of for my use, but if I let it to a pewterer again—they were under the prisoner's protection, be
cause he had the house—I do not know that they were under his protec
tion for my use—they were for my use to sell again if I chose, to be disposed of to a pewterer—that understanding, about their being under his protection, was come to after I gave him the key.
COURT. Q. Was there anything said about them? A. No.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Do you mean nothing was said about these goods from beginning to end? A. No, there was nothing said about the furnace and chimneys—all the articles were placed in this outhouse—nothing was said to him about the articles that were placed in that out-house—there were some loose things, and them I fastened up in a box—I sent the box to lock them all up in, and they were not to be disturbed—he was not to let any other person have them.

Q. Were they not under his protection, though they were your pro
perty? A. When I lent him the key, I expected it to be returned; but when he had got the things locked up I did not ask him for it again—What Was there, was my property—he was not to disturb them—I did not tell him to take care of them—I did not at any time tell him they were to be taken care of for me—I did not tell him what was in the show him what was there—I did not remove the fixtures from the house to this place—I did not remove a single thing from the front house to this place—I do not know that they were put there by my orders—Was in the front shop was about a dozen and a half of pots and, some measures, that I allowed the prisoner to have to get the windows mended—I ask for the key afterwards when he had been a few days in possession of it—the key was in the door—I saw it in the door—I went in and saw all the things safe—when I came out I think I took the key—yes, I must have done so, or else how came he to ask me for it—after I had given him the key I asked him for it—I went and found it in the door—I left it in the door.

Q. You said you took the key? A. In first first instance I took the key, and then I think he had it again; but I found it in the door—my son was backwards and forwards, looking after the things—the prisoner got the key from me—he said he wanted to put some things in, and I found was two crates—I cannot charge my memory whether he asked me for that key after that occasion—it passed backwards and forwards two or three times—I cannot say what was the last occasion on which I gave him the key—it was to move out what he had got in—I did not ask him for the key after that—I considered the things were safe, and therefore did not ask him for it—I considered he was taking care of them—these pre
mises had formerly been used for a pewteier—the things in this indictment were articles for the purpose of pewtering—the prisoner was a beer-shop keeper—he put up some things for the purpose of carrying on the Alton
ale business—there was not less than twenty squares of glass to be put in when he got into the house—he put some in—I agreed to allow him 1s. a foot for the glass, and 6d. a square for taking the old broken glass out—I did hot come after he had been in some time, ask him It he would dispose of any of the articles at the back of the shop—none at all—I know Mr. Barnett—he bought the things—I do not know Mr. Church or Mr. Paisley—I have seen Mr. Church within the last two or three days—I have seen Mr. paisley two or three days in Court—I have not told them that I authorised the prisoner to sell these articles for the best price he could get—to the best of my knowledge, I never saw them till I saw them in this Court—I did not call on the prisoner on the 2nd of May, to my know
ledge—it might be on the 2nd of May—he did not tell me he could get 9l. 10s. for the things, if I approved of that sum, nor that if he were to sell these things I must allow him 3l. 10s. to paint the back and front windows, and to paint and grain the shutters—he did not paint the back

and front—I paid the bill for it in his shop—that was after he went in, to the best of my recollection—he did not tell me he had sold these things for twelve guineas, and he was to receive half in money and half in coppers—he told me he had got some coppers for sale, and if I knew any one who would buy them they should have them at 1s. a pound, and I told him to let me have one to look at—he did not tell me he had sold them for twelve guineas, that he had half in money and half in coppers, and if I would take the coppers it would make up the rent—he was not to sell anything, but to send people to me—he did not sell any articles to Hudson—that was before he got into the house—I let the prisoner have part of the things in the front house, consisting of measures and brass taps, and other things, for mending the windows—they are not included in this indictment—I have an inventory of them in my pocket—I did not tell Mr. Barnett that I allowed the prisoner to sell the things, and he was to have 2l. or 8l. if he could do it—I did not tell Mr. Barnett, if he would not say anything about that when he came here on the trial, that I would not sue him for the money on the things—I declare to heaven I did not—I took possession of the premises when I found the prisoner was gone, about seven o'clock in the morning of the quarter
day.

MR. BALDWIN. Q. The prisoner asked you for the key of this out-house to put some things in? A. Yes, for a lodger that he had got, and I saw two crates in it—they hid the furnace, and I could not see that it was gone—I cannot say whether the crates were placed one on the other or not—I ordered the box to go, and the things were secured in it—I had a great deal of conversation with Mr. Barnett about the things after I traced them—one was a great fly-wheel, seven feet in diameter—I had conversation with Mr. Barnett a fortnight after the house was left—I have seen him standing, here—I heard the prisoner had two executions in his house—at the time I gave him the key I did not give him any control over these things—I took it for granted he would not interfere with them—I do not remember precisely at what time he asked for the key—it might be a fort-night or three weeks after he had the premises—he put up some taps and vats for the Alton ale—he took everything away again—the house was gutted.

JAMES BARNETT . I am a coppersmith, with Mr. Pontifex—I carry on business in Dover-road. I know the prisoner—I purchased these things of him about the 8th of May—he came to me, and I went to the premises where these things were—he said he had purchased the fixtures and tools for 60l., and he asked me twenty guineas for them—my foreman valued them, and I gave him 12l. for them—I purchased them all at once.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you bad any conversation with Mr. Rice about this case? A. I have—he told me the prisoner was to sell them, and have a profit of 3l., or something of that kind—I mentioned to the prosecutor that he had authorized the prisoner to sell them, and that he might get 2l. or 3l. by selling them.

COURT. Q. Did you tell Mr. Rice that he himself had said he autho
rized the prisoner to sell them? A. I said, "You authorized the pri
soner to sell them, and be might get 2l. or 3l. by them;" he said so to me in my premises—when he first came to me about them he said he had authorized him to sell them, and he thought he might get 1l. or 2l. him
self—I mentioned that afterwards to Mr. Rice when I went before the Grand Jury—he said it was false, he never said anything of the kind—I
said, "You have forgotten it, sir; you really did say so;" and he really said so.
JURY. Q. Do you recollect the former part of the conversation? A. I do not—he came to inquire if we had bought the things—I candidly told him we had, and then he said what I have stated.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Has Mr. Rice since that time promised not to sue you forthe value of the things if you would not say that? A. tanta-mount; to that—he begged, as a favour, that I would not say anything about it, because he wished to prosecute the man.

COURT. Q. Have I this right?—when Mr. Rice first came to you he said; "I authorised him to sell the things, and he might get 2l. or 3l. upon them? A. The tools, my Lord—I put him in mind of it before the Grand Jury, and he denied it, and said it was false—I said, "You may have forgotten it."

Q. And then you say he begged it as a favour that you would not say anything about it, as he wished to prosecute the man? A. Through an
other party, my Lord—Mr. Rice did not say that—he said the first part, that he authorized the prisoner.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Through whom did he say that? A. Through the policeman—church and Paisly are both in my employ—I mentioned publicly in my shop when I went from the Old Bailey what Mr. Rice had first said to me.

MR. BALDWIN. Q. Do you mean positively to swear that the prose
cutor made use of that expression to you when he came about these things? A. He did—I can swear to it—It was not what the prisoner said—he said nothing of the kind—I am not confounding what the prisoner laid with what the prosecutor said—the prosecutor said he told him to sell the things, that he might get a pound or two by them himself—I am not aware that I ever mentioned that circumstance before—I was in the Police-court, but was not called on, or I should have stated it there——I stated it in the clerk's office—I made a deposition at the police-office—I was sworn to tell the whole truth, and nothing but the truth do not know that I stated one word about the prosecutor having said this to me—my deposition was read over to me, and I signed it in the clerk's office—I was sworn—I think it was in the clerk's office—the pr said he autliorised the prisoner to sell the tools—he did not say a word about the fixtures.

JOHN DALTON . I am the prosecutor's servant In April last, I went to these premises to pack up a lot of tools in the back workshop, is a building on the other side of the yard—I went into the building for that purpose—I put the tools into the chest, and corded it up—I did not see the prisoner—I saw wit wife.

cross-examined. Q. Did you take the key, or get it from the prisoner's wife? A. It was not locked, it was open—it was in the spring—I do not know the month—I took no key—I do not recollect the prisoner going into the house.
JOHN PURSER (police-constable M 87.) I took the prisoner on this charge—he stated that he purchased the goods from Mr. Rice, and he did not consider Mr. Rice had anything to do with him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not he say that That did not consider that Mr. Rice had any claim upon him, except for rent? A. I think he did—to the best of my belief I did not go from Mr. Rice to Mr. Barnett with any

message—I do not believe I did—I did not go to Mr. Barnett, and tell him not to mention what he had been told by Mr. Rice, as Mr. Rice wished to prosecute the prisoner—I went to Mr. Barnett last Thursday evening, after I left the Court to tell him what time to come in the morn
ing—I did not say that Mr. Rice hoped he would not mention what he said to him, as he wished to prosecute the man—I swear I did not tell him anything else, except to tell him to be here in the morning—Mr. Rice gave me no message—I have spoken to him about this case several times—I did not tell him that I had heard he had told Mr. Barnett that he authorised the prisoner to sell these things—I have heard it whispered about—I have never told Mr. Rice, at any time; nor spoken to him About what he said, no more than I stated in my deposition, that the prisoner Said he bought them of Mr. Rice, and he did not consider he had anything to do with him.
MR. BALDWIN. Q. had Mr. Barnett been here on the Thursday? A. No, he had not.
MR. HUDDLESTON to MR. RICE. Q. Did you send any message by the policeman to Mr. Barnett? A. Certainly not; none whatever.

JAMES DORE . I live in Lant-street, in the Borough—I have known the prisoner about two years—he has been an honest man as far as I have known and heard—I called at his house one morning, in May, and heard Mr. Rice drive up with his horse and gig, with footman with him—he got out of the gig, came in front of the bar, and said, "Mr. Crussell, have you sold those things of mine yet?"—crussell's reply was, "No, I have not yet, Sir"—he said, "I wish you would"—Mr. Crussell said, "I had an offer for them yesterday, and I can get 12l. for them, half in money, and half in goods"—Mr. Rice's reply was, "What goods?"—he said, "Coppers"—Mr. Rice made a reply, and said, "I wish you would sell them, and do the best you can with them;" and he said, "Good morn
ing," and went away—Mr. Crussell sard, "That was ray landlord."

MR. BALDWIN. Q. When did this take place? A. I do not know—it was some morning in May, from ten to eleven o'clock—I do not remem
ber the day of the week, nor the day of the month—it was in the month of May—I would not say what day—I think about the 7th or 8th of May—I was in the habit of calling at Mr. Crussell's house, and other houses, for orders for cigars and tobacco on my own account—I saw Mr. Rice and his servant come there with a gig—I did not know Mr. Rice before, but Mr. Crussiell said that was his landlord—there was only me, and Mr. Rice, and the prisoner, and the footman, there, and the gig outside—this was in front of the bar in the Prince of Wales, in the Dover-road—there was no one else present—the prosecutor said, "Mr. Crussell, have you sold those things yet?"—these were the words—there was nothing said about fixtures—he said, "Those things in the back premises"—back premises were men
tioned—I said the things in the back premises—Mr. Rice did not come in a carriage—it was a horse and two-wheeled gig, like what some of the doctors drive—I saw it.

Q. Just repeat what passed? A. Mr. Rice asked Crussell if he had sold the things in the back work-shop—I mean to swear those were the words used—I swear that I heard Mr. Rice ask Mr. Crussell whether he had sold those things in the workshop—Mr. Rice's words were, "Those things belonging tame in the back workshop"—I have been here attend
ing

all the week—I have not spoken to the solicitor, or to any one—I came here merely to stale what I heard—I certainly did not tell any onwe that I came to state this—I thought these things had better e kept in, than to tell people outside—I have been outside whife this case was going on—I mentioned it to the man who keeps, the door—there have been a great many people outside with me—we have been all talking about it, and it is possible we have while the case was going on—I do not know how long the case has been going on—I did not tell the prisoner about it—I have never seen him from the time he left the Court at Union-hall till this time.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. The prisoner told, Mr. Rice he had had an offer of twelve guieas, half money aud half goods? A. Yes and he said, "Take and sell them, and do the best you can"—I stated this to the solicitor a week ago—I told him the same words I have stated now.

CHARLES SMITH . Iam a general dealer, and live at Camberwell. I was with Mr. Crussell when he sold these things to Mr. Barnett—I saw Mr. Rice at Mr. Crnssell's one morning, five or six months ago he came and asked Mr. Crussell if he had got those coppers for them—Mr. Crussell said he had not, he had been disappoisted about them; but he would go and see if he could get, them that same day—I did not hear about the other things.

MR. BALDWIN to CHRLES RICE. Q. Did you, May last go to the prisoner's house in a two-wheeled gig with your servant? A. I did not—I have a gig, but I did not see Dore, nor did I desire the prisoner, to sell this property.

COURT. Q. Did you go in any other carriage? A. I have called as I have gone by I have called repeatedly—I never went to ask the prisinor if he had sold the things—I called to see if the things we were safe when I heard what sort of a man had got there.

MR. HUDDLESTON Q. Did you see the things? A. I saw the things in the front place, and I saw the things that are stated—I was in and out several times—I passed the door, every day to go to the City—I drove my gig twelve months ago, but I did not in May—I could not undertake to swear I did not drive it in May—I do not think I did—I have put it on one side for some time—I think I did not—I did not drive it in May—I have a Clarence with four wheels a gig—I have two vehicles—I had not the gig in May, now I come to recollect, it was in the Isle of Thanet—to the best of my recollection I did not drive that gig or any gig in May—I think my gig was in the contry—I do not know that I can undertake to swear I did not drive it in May, it was so near a point when I had it away—I do not book these things—I think I may have said I did not drive it in May—I cannot tell indeed—I should rather say I did not drive it in May than that I did—I do not know—I might have driven it in May—I never saw Dore till I saw him here—I got one copper as a sample to sell for the prisoner, but that was on another concern.

COURT. Q. Did you get one copper from him? A. Yes, one as a sample—he said he had got a quantity to sell—he wanted 1s. a pound for them—I said I knew a gentleman who was building some houses—it was to sell for the prisoner.
MR. BALDWIN to JOHN DALTON. Q. Are you in the habit of going out with your master in the gig or Clarence? A. Yes—I cannot say
which he drove in May—he has ridden in both since I have been with him, but not in the gig for some time.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you driven your master to the prisoner's house? A. We called there a great many times, but I do not recollect whether in the gig or in the Clarence.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Twelve Months.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2181.
GEORGE MARTIN was indicted
for stealing 1 sovereign, and 1 half-sovereign, the monies of
Charles Davis, his master.

SARAH DAVIS . I am the wife of Charles Davis; we live in Cornwall-road, Lambeth; the prisoner worked with my husband. I put a sovereign and a half-sovereign into a box on the 27th of Sept.—the prisoner, my little girl, and the other children, were in the room—I went away, leaving the prisoner in the room—I afterwards missed the money—I found the prisoner at the Surrey theatre at one o'clock in the morning.

SARAH ANN DAVIS . I was in the room when the money was put there—the children were going to school—the prisoner told me to go and open the door, and when I came in I saw him putting up the box that the money was in—he walked up and down the room three times, and then he said, "I will go and buy a halfpenny-worth of apples"—he went out, and did not return—he ought to have come back to work—no one else came in but my mother, which was in about an hour and a half afterwards.
JAMES ANDREWS (police-constable L 130.) I took the prisoner—he said he had never seen any of the money, and if he had, if there was no money found on him, we could do nothing with him.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not have it; I did not know it was there.

GUILTY .* Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

2182.
GEORGE SIDNEY HEATH was indicted
for stealing 2 feet of zinc pipe, value 2s., the goods of
Robert Wardle and others.—2nd Count, stating it to be the goods of
Frederick Giles.

ABRAHAM PENTLETON . I am watchman of Vauxhall-gardens. There was a grea't quantity of zinc pipe about the gardens—we have missed thirty or forty feet of it—it belonged to Mr. Frederick Giles when he was the manager there—the place belongs to Mr. Robert Wardle and others—I believe this to be some of that pipe—I have no doubt of it.

WILLIAM HOWSON . I am a marine-store dealer, and live in Vauxhall-street. On the 29th of Oct. the prisoner brought a piece of iron to me—he gave me his address—he returned, and asked me if I bought zinc pipe—I said yes—he went away, and I communicated with an officer, knowing there had been some lost from the gardens—the prisoner brought this pipe, and the officer took him.
Prisoner. I picked it up in Moss fields.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

2183.
CATHERINE ALLEN
was. indicted for stealing 1 watch, value 2l. 15s.; guard chain, 12s.; and 1 handkerchief, 3s.; the goods of
John Mackinlay, from his person; and that she had been before convicted of felony.
JOHN MACKINLAY . I am an engineer, and live in Richard-terrace, Black friars-road. About two o'clock in the morning of the 28th of Oct.,

I was in Waterloo-road—the prisoner came up to me two or three times—I told her to be gone—she went on, and made a stand still—the officer came, and said, "You will lose your watch and your guard"—I went on down Webber-street, and the prisoner knocked off my hat—I went to get it, and she gave me a sudden thrust, and took my watch off,' whether over my head or what, I do not know—I went and got the officer, and told him—I saw the prisoner again the next night at a public-house—she asked me to have some gin—I said, "No, I want to talk to you—what have you done with that property of mine?"—she said, "What property?"—I said, "That watch and things"—she made dreadful oaths, and said she was in bed by half-past ten that night—I said the best thing she could do was to come with me—I told her if she had pawned it to give me the duplicate, and I would say no more—she then said she wished she might be struck blind if the was the person—she ran off—I went and caught her, and brought her back to Oakley-street till an officer came, and she was brought to the station—I am sure she is the person.

Prisoner. He knows I am not the person; the superintendent would not take the charge till he went for the other constable; how could I knock his hat off, and take his watch and chain? I saw him the next night at this public-house, and is it likely I should go there?—he was drinking with me and some other women on Monday night; he left the others, and came out and walked with me; the policeman told him he would be robbed, and he said he knew me better than the officer did; I went home and went to bed, and I told him to go to bed.

HENRY PROWSE (police-constable L 102.) I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor at the corner of a, court—I cautioned him that if he did not mind he would lose his watch—the prisoner was with him, and in four or five minutes he complained of the loss of his watch—the prisoner heard me caution him.

Prisoner. Yes, and he said he knew me perfectly well; he said he would treat me; I went to the public-house; there were othet females and males that he treated as well as me; we then walked up Webber-street, and the officer said to him, "Do you know who you are with? she is a common prostitute;" he said he did not thank him for his information. I went home and went to bed. I live at No. 25, Gloucester-street. The prosecutor came to me the next night, and said, "Where is my watch?" I said, "I know nothing about it;" he said, "Will you come to the station?" I said, "By all means;" he has known me two or three years.

JURY to JOHN MACKINLAY. Q. Did you know where the prisoner lived? A. No, I never saw her before—we went to several places, and could not find her—we went to the house where she said she lived, and she had left that house.

ROBERT BARTLETT (police-constable L 188.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted 14th April, 1845, and confined six months)—she is the person, and she has been summarily convicted many times.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Transported for Ten Years.
ADJOURNED TILL MONDAY, 24TH OF NOVEMBER.
